title: Love Songs, Liturgy, Laments: Sumerian and Its Emesal “Dialect”
description:
Sumerian literature employs two “dialects”: a main dialect called Emegir, a language of myths, poems, and hymns, which was also used in texts outside literature such as royal inscriptions, letters, and contracts; and a type of dialect or sociolect called Emesal, the “thin language,” which was often interpreted as a language of women or female characters, particularly goddesses. Emesal is characterized by a number of phonological differences from the main dialect, which often appear written syllabically. The first session of this course highlights previous research on Emesal, its sources, and tools. For the remainder of the term we read a selection of literary compositions that are composed in the Emesal dialect or at least partially adhere to it. Although the focus is on texts dating to the Old Babylonian period, we also read later Emesal literature, in particular bilingual liturgical texts.

Prerequisite: previous study of Sumerian.
